required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Pilot Study of Transforaminal Epidural Injection of Clonidine for the Treatment of Acute Lumbosacral Radiculopathy

brief_summary.textblock: This was a randomized, blinded study of transforaminal epidural injection of clonidine versus a similar injection of corticosteroid for acute lumbosacral radiculopathy. The hypothesis was that clonidine will be as effective as steroid for this condition.

detailed_description.textblock: Patients with approximately 3 months of low back pain and leg pain due to intervertebral disc herniation were randomized to transforaminal epidural injections of 2% lidocaine and either clonidine (200 or 400 micrograms) or triamcinolone (40 mg) (corticosteroid). Patients received one to three injections administered at about 2 weeks apart. Patients, investigators, and study coordinators were blinded to the treatment. The primary outcome was an 11-point Pain Intensity Numerical Rating Scale at 1 month. The hypothesis was that clonidine will be as effective as steroid for this condition.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Pain Intensity Score at 4 Weeks as Measured by Pain Intensity Numerical Rating Scale (PI-NRS)
primary_outcome.description: 11-point ordinal scale measuring patient pain, ranging from 0 (no pain) to 10 (most severe/disabling pain).

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain Intensity Score at 2 Weeks as Measured by Pain Intensity Numerical Rating Scale (PI-NRS)
secondary_outcome.description: 11-point ordinal scale measuring patient pain, ranging from 0 (no pain) to 10 (most severe/disabling pain).

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain Disability Score at 2 Weeks as Measured by the Roland-Morris Disability Questionnaire
secondary_outcome.description: This scale measures functional disability due to back pain. The score of the scale is the total number of items checked, from a minimum of 0 (no disability) to a maximum of 24 (great disability). Roland MO, Morris RW. A study of the natural history of back Pain. Part 1: development of a reliable and sensitive measure of disability in low back pain. Spine 1983; 8:141-144.

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain Disability Score at 4 Weeks as Measured by the Roland-Morris Disability Questionnaire
secondary_outcome.description: This scale measures functional disability due to back pain. The score of the scale is the total number of items checked, from a minimum of 0 (no disability) to a maximum of 24 (great disability). Roland MO, Morris RW. A study of the natural history of back Pain. Part 1: development of a reliable and sensitive measure of disability in low back pain. Spine 1983; 8:141-144.

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain Disability Score at 2 Weeks as Measured by Oswestry Low Back Pain Disability Questionnaire (ODI)
secondary_outcome.description: This questionnaire measures a patient's permanent functional disability. The questionnaire consists of 10 sections with 6 statements each of increasing point value (from 0 to 5). The score is a percentage of the total, with higher score showing greater disability. Minimum detectable change is 10%, with a 90% CI. Change of less than this may be attributable to error in measurement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain Disability Score at 4 Weeks as Measured by Oswestry Low Back Pain Disability Questionnaire
secondary_outcome.description: This questionnaire measures a patient's permanent functional disability. The questionnaire consists of 10 sections with 6 statements each of increasing point value (from 0 to 5). The score is a percentage of the total, with higher score showing greater disability. Minimum detectable change is 10%, with a 90% CI. Change of less than this may be attributable to error in measurement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain Score at 2 Weeks as Measured by the Multidimensional Pain Inventory (MPI)
secondary_outcome.description: The MPI is a comprehensive instrument comprised of 12 scales divided into three parts for assessing a number of dimensions of the chronic pain experience including pain intensity, emotional distress, cognitive and functional adaptation, and social support. Reference: Kearns RO, Turk DC, Rudy TC. The West Haven-Yale Multidimensional Pain Inventory (WHYMPI). Pain 1985; 23:345-356. Subscales were not used; the DOS WHYMPI computer program version 2.1 was used to score the instrument. Scores range from 0 (no pain) to 100 (highest pain). A score of 50 is the mean for patients with chronic pain.

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain Score at 4 Weeks as Measured by the Multidimensional Pain Inventory (MPI)
secondary_outcome.description: The MPI is a comprehensive instrument comprised of 12 scales divided into three parts for assessing a number of dimensions of the chronic pain experience including pain intensity, emotional distress, cognitive and functional adaptation, and social support. Reference: Kearns RO, Turk DC, Rudy TC. The West Haven-Yale Multidimensional Pain Inventory (WHYMPI). Pain 1985; 23:345-356. Subscales were not used; the DOS WHYMPI computer program version 2.1 was used to score the instrument. Scores range from 0 (no pain) to 100 (highest pain). A score of 50 is the mean for patients with chronic pain.

clinical_study.condition: Lumbar and Other Intervertebral Disc Disorders With Radiculopathy

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Residents 18 years or older of Olmsted or contiguous counties and identified as having an acute unilateral radicular syndrome of less than 3 months duration (leg pain>back, discogenic cause, one or more of the following:
- Positive Straight Leg Raise (SLR) test
- Myotomal weakness
- Dermatomal sensory loss) and with concordant
- Confirmatory findings on recent MRI or CT myelogram
Exclusion Criteria:
- History of recent spinal trauma
- Cauda equina syndrome (This is a serious neurologic condition in which there is acute loss of function of the lumbar plexus, neurologic elements of the spinal canal below the termination of the spinal cord.)
- Progressive neurological deficit
- Motor deficit
- Pathological or infectious etiology
- Involvement in workers' compensation claim
- History of adverse reaction to corticosteroids, local anesthetic or clonidine
- History of one or more corticosteroid injection(s) (equivalent to 40 mg of triamcinolone acetate) in the preceding 4 months
- Pregnant
- Severe medical disease

results_reference.citation: Burgher AH, Hoelzer BC, Schroeder DR, Wilson GA, Huntoon MA. Transforaminal epidural clonidine versus corticosteroid for acute lumbosacral radiculopathy due to intervertebral disc herniation. Spine (Phila Pa 1976). 2011 Mar 1;36(5):E293-300. doi: 10.1097/BRS.0b013e3181ddd597.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Of the 33 patients screened and randomized, 26 enrolled.

group.title: 2% Lidocaine and Clonidine (200 or 400 ug)
group.description: Patients received one to three injections administered at about 2 weeks apart. Patients,investigators, and study coordinators were blinded to the treatment. The primary outcome was an 11-point Pain Intensity Numerical Rating Scale at 1 month. Other outcomes included Patient Global Impression of Change and functional measures.

group.title: 2% Lidocaine and Triamcinolone (40 mg).
group.description: Patients received one to three injections administered at about 2 weeks apart. Patients,investigators, and study coordinators were blinded to the treatment. The primary outcome was an 11-point Pain Intensity Numerical Rating Scale at 1 month. Other outcomes included Patient Global Impression of Change and functional measures.

The primary outcome was an 11-point Pain Intensity Numerical Rating Scale at 1 month. Other outcomes included Patient Global Impression of Change and functional measures.

measure.title: Pain Intensity Score
measure.description: Pain Intensity Score as measured by Pain Intensity Numerical Rating Scale (PI-NRS). This is an 11-point ordinal scale measuring patient pain, ranging from 0 (no pain) to 10 (most severe/disabling pain).

outcome.title: Pain Intensity Score at 4 Weeks as Measured by Pain Intensity Numerical Rating Scale (PI-NRS)
outcome.description: 11-point ordinal scale measuring patient pain, ranging from 0 (no pain) to 10 (most severe/disabling pain).

measure.title: Pain Intensity Score at 4 Weeks as Measured by Pain Intensity Numerical Rating Scale (PI-NRS)
measure.description: 11-point ordinal scale measuring patient pain, ranging from 0 (no pain) to 10 (most severe/disabling pain).

analysis.groups_desc: Data were analyzed using analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) with baseline value included as a covariate.

outcome.title: Pain Disability Score at 2 Weeks as Measured by the Roland-Morris Disability Questionnaire
outcome.description: This scale measures functional disability due to back pain. The score of the scale is the total number of items checked, from a minimum of 0 (no disability) to a maximum of 24 (great disability). Roland MO, Morris RW. A study of the natural history of back Pain. Part 1: development of a reliable and sensitive measure of disability in low back pain. Spine 1983; 8:141-144.

outcome.title: Pain Disability Score at 2 Weeks as Measured by Oswestry Low Back Pain Disability Questionnaire (ODI)
outcome.description: This questionnaire measures a patient's permanent functional disability. The questionnaire consists of 10 sections with 6 statements each of increasing point value (from 0 to 5). The score is a percentage of the total, with higher score showing greater disability. Minimum detectable change is 10%, with a 90% CI. Change of less than this may be attributable to error in measurement.

measure.title: Pain Disability Score at 2 Weeks as Measured by Oswestry Low Back Pain Disability Questionnaire (ODI)
measure.description: This questionnaire measures a patient's permanent functional disability. The questionnaire consists of 10 sections with 6 statements each of increasing point value (from 0 to 5). The score is a percentage of the total, with higher score showing greater disability. Minimum detectable change is 10%, with a 90% CI. Change of less than this may be attributable to error in measurement.

outcome.title: Pain Score at 2 Weeks as Measured by the Multidimensional Pain Inventory (MPI)
outcome.description: The MPI is a comprehensive instrument comprised of 12 scales divided into three parts for assessing a number of dimensions of the chronic pain experience including pain intensity, emotional distress, cognitive and functional adaptation, and social support. Reference: Kearns RO, Turk DC, Rudy TC. The West Haven-Yale Multidimensional Pain Inventory (WHYMPI). Pain 1985; 23:345-356. Subscales were not used; the DOS WHYMPI computer program version 2.1 was used to score the instrument. Scores range from 0 (no pain) to 100 (highest pain). A score of 50 is the mean for patients with chronic pain.

measure.title: Pain Score at 2 Weeks as Measured by the Multidimensional Pain Inventory (MPI)
measure.description: The MPI is a comprehensive instrument comprised of 12 scales divided into three parts for assessing a number of dimensions of the chronic pain experience including pain intensity, emotional distress, cognitive and functional adaptation, and social support. Reference: Kearns RO, Turk DC, Rudy TC. The West Haven-Yale Multidimensional Pain Inventory (WHYMPI). Pain 1985; 23:345-356. Subscales were not used; the DOS WHYMPI computer program version 2.1 was used to score the instrument. Scores range from 0 (no pain) to 100 (highest pain). A score of 50 is the mean for patients with chronic pain.

analysis.groups_desc: Data were analyzed using analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) with baseline value included as a covariate.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Early termination leading to small numbers of subjects analyzed; did not measure analgesia during the expected analgesic peak of bolus administration, but 10 days after last injection; compared clonidine with an active control, rather than placebo.
